Gotta say it'd be interesting to see this test repeated, but with either multiple shots, or preloading the suppressor with an inert gas like nitrogen. There have been multiple videos showing how many suppressor designs are louder on the first shot than the subsequent shots, with the claim usually being that the suppressor is full of normal air and hence oxygen for the first shot. That oxygen is burnt during the shot, and contributes to the sound, but for the follow up shots the can has a lot less oxygen in it.

Would be interesting to see if we could see the difference even visually, with less obvious burning happening in the can.

As a California resident, I was initially baffled by this episode's title — What's a "suppressor"?  Suppress what?  Ohhhh...  SOUND.  I get it.  The epic quest for a kinder, gentler automatic weapon, with less noise pollution.  Cool.  I guess.  But I have to wonder —  the primary use of automatic weapons in domestic culture is in gang warfare and organized crime, where noise is presumably a desirable effect.  So in what application would noise suppression be desirable?  Then I remembered.  The next most common use of automatic weapons is in pest control, i.e. suppression of the population of school children.  Thinning the herd.  It's not desirable to unduly scare the grade 1-3 population during thinning operations on the 4-8 grade population, hence the need for noise suppression.  Better living through technology.

I've always wondered if a larger gas strut, say the size of automobile shock could move fast enough to capture a large portion of the gases just exiting the barrel. I had a muzzle brake/flash suppressor on my Mini 14 that could have been used in a homemade test. A conventional suppressor could then be used to capture the remaining gases and be mounted on the end of the muzzle brake. The pneumatic cylinder could be placed anywhere, probably
under the barrel with a shroud over the "muzzle brake" directing the gases to the cylinder. It might even work on full auto if the piston can return quickly enough. Obviously bulkiness, if it even works, is an issue, but It seems like it would be very quiet!

Got to love "Stamp Collectors" dB info would have been a nice add. Looks vs. Performance.. Other things that are important are bullet impact shift,  blowback pressures in semi automatic weapons, weight, size, and ease of cleaning. It ain't easy. Some good ones: Silencer co., AAC, Liberty (Dave another good ol boy, fantastic co. FYI) to name a few..  Lawnmowers have mufflers so should guns.

Reasons to own suppressors:
Target shooting: Shooting ANY firearm (even while wearing earmuffs) is more than enough to cause hearing loss over time. Having earmuffs AND a suppressor, is proper hearing protection.
Good manners: Some people out in the country, might not like listening to neighbors sight in their hunting rifles. I'd personally like to keep the neighbors happy if possible.
Hunting: Ever fire a rifle in the silence of the forest? That's VERY bad for your hearing. I don't want hunters losing their hearing, over something as stupid as the current process for legally getting suppressors.
Home defense: Like hunters, a lot of people who are prepared for a possible home invasion, choose not to wear hearing protection. Wouldn't want some dastardly assailant to sneak up on you right? And there aren't a lot of things louder than shooting a long gun in the house.
Learning tool: New shooters can be intimidated by a gun. They'll flinch and miss because they're anticipating the noise and recoil. Suppressors (along with their obvious effect) help lower recoil to an extent. If it makes their first shooting experience more enjoyable and doesn't hurt anyone, then I'm all for it.

The failure of the display piece suppressor looks like it was put into a standing wave by the gasses. That would be a stress on any jacket put on the suppressor.

In all the other suppressors, there are more channels for the gasses to move through and to dissipate the kinetic energy of the gasses. The muzzle end of the display suppressor did not have any baffles for the segment that failed. It seems to me that more baffles throughout the suppressor is the solution, and it would act like when marching soldiers break step over a bridge: it prevents energy from finding a resonance point that makes a standing wave. A standing wave grows stronger and stronger the more times it is allowed to resonate, and standing waves can destroy muzzles, bridges, and even the plaza of the MGM Grand Hotel back a few decades ago.

Destin, I think the reason it failed was not necessarily due to the axial component of the stress alone.  It seems to me what happened is that the hoop direction stress stretched the acrylic until you lost enough thread engagement at the aft end for the axial to overcome the shear resistance of the threads due to not as much contact.  That would be my guess based on the fact that hoop direction stress in a cylinder under pressure is twice that of the axial stress (pressure x radius/2xthickness for axial vs (pressure x radius/thickness in hoop).

In case anyone is wondering, yes, you should still wear ear protection when using a suppressor. That is unless you are using sub-sonic ammunition, then it's hearing safe. With standard ammo, unless it's, for example, 45 acp, most are breaking the sound barrier which is the loud crack heard along with the sound of the muzzle blast. The loud crack of the bullet breaking the sound barrier isn't technically hearing safe. (can cause hearing damage) Suppressors have wide usage. No, it's not like the movies being nearly silent taking everyone out with nobody hearing. They are used for things like hunting, defense, and some stealth. Take, for example, if god forbid, you need to use a firearm to protect yourself or family while inside your home (someone breaks in) having a suppressor on your firearm is a good thing. Idk if any of you have fired a firearm such as a rifle, pistol or shotgun in an enclosed space without hearing pro but I have. (I was being a dumbass) It's defining and can cause severe hearing loss.

Destin, The diamond flow channels got me thinking about a suppressor utilizing the Tesla Flow Valve. You might mention that to Steve. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_valve. That might take some of the longitudinal load off the outer shell of acrylic and keep it on the aluminium. It seemed like the gasses slamming into the downrange end of the suppressor is what pulled it off the muzzle and caused it to fail.

In that first shot, I think there's more going on than just increased pressure inside the tube. I believe there is also a fairly significant low pressure area that trails the bullet after leaving the suppressor, creating fairly strong suction.

My basis for this is that the cover on my suppressor worked loose one day and protruded forward of the front face. When I fired, the cover was launched ~15m down range. I can't think of any other forces acting on the suppressor cover that would have caused such a forward motion, so my best guess is that the pressure differential "sucked" the cover off. It seems like that was probably also one of the factors influencing the tube in your first shot.

This is truly awesome! The suppressor tested around the 3:30 mark has something really interesting, and I don't think the designers quite realized what they did, and Destin didn't realize it or he would have commented on it. The features at the front of the suppressor is actually a quenching section, which cools the gasses by forcing the hot gasses to transfer its heat to the metal. When the hot gas cools the volume in turn decreases, which reduces the sound signature. As the suppressor gets hotter, this effect reduces a little, but it's the first time I've seen actual quenching used in a suppressor. This is why the old suppressors with steel wool in them worked so well; there was massive surface area to transfer the heat to, but the wool didn't last very long because it rusted from the heat and moisture, not to mention heated up quickly, reducing its ability to absorb more heat.

Why do you say the acrylic suppressor casings fail with axial stresses? I'd suggest that it's a hoop stress/strain problem which, because of the lower elastic modulus of acrylic, would allow the threads to disengage. The rifle barrel end of the suppressor would see a higher peak pressure, hence higher hoop stress (and thus strain), so would fail preferentially. If you preloaded the threaded end of the acrylic with some kind of compressive shrink collar or collet/taper arrangement, you might avoid this problem.

The last suppressor showed that the blast exiting the muzzle is reflected back toward the rifle much like a pressure pulse is reflected reverse stream (rearwards) during a water hammer or simple nozzle exit event.  This secondary pulse, travelling in the reverse direction from the initial pulse should be reflected also.  I would put an additional reflector at the initial entrance directed in the reverse direction to the downstream reflectors.  This would alter the forces on the threaded end and lessen the impact of the pulse.
